details.title: The use of residuals in statistical modeling for fatigue-crack growth under constant amplitude loading
details.standardTitle: The use of residuals in statistical modeling for fatigue-crack growth under constant amplitude loading

p: Michael E. Robinson received the B. Sc. degree in mathematics and statistics and the Ph. D. degree in statistics from Lancaster University, UK. His major research involved environmental extreme values, but he has also made important contributions to the analysis of sports and athletics data.
He went on to Surrey University, working on crack growth models, and is now a quantitative financial analyst in the City of London.

authors.affiliation: Man Investment Products Ltd., London, UK
authors.name: M.E. Robinson

p: Martin J. Crowder received the B. Sc. degree in mathematics from Manchester University, the Diploma in statistics from Imperial College, and the Ph.D. degree in statistics from Surrey University, UK.
He has worked in a variety of areas of statistics, including mathematical theory and engineering applications. He is a reader in statistics at Imperial College, London.

details.abstract: Various models have been proposed over the years to fit crack growth data. Many papers have appeared in which one or more models are mooted and fitted, and various assessments made of the quality of the fit. At the basic level the data are plotted, together with the fitted curve, to show agreement of experimental and predicted values. In this paper we suggest that it can be useful and informative to go one step further, examining the residuals, i.e., the differences between the experimental and predicted values. We draw attention to certain statistical methods for such critical assessment and show by example that this can reveal deficiencies in fit not otherwise obvious. In this way suitable modifications to the model can be suggested. Additional plots of estimated parameters are also shown to be informative about models.

context.text: In the statistical literature, many techniques can be found for analyzing repeated measures made on similar specimens over a period of time (e.g., [1] and the references therein).
A suitable statistical model to fit to the crack growth for each specimen is a nonlinear growth-curve model, e.g., [1].

context.text: Section II lists several previously proposed crack growth laws and describes the fatigue-crack growth data-set, introduced in [5], which is used throughout this paper for illustration.
Section IV analyzes the data in [5], identifying the most appropriate crack growth law, and accounting for the persistent deviations from it.
Fatigue-crack growth data for 56 specimens [5].
A typical data set, although one of the most extensive, is that introduced in [5].
Full details of the experiment are in [5].
Such errors, and their potential magnitude, are discussed in [5].
Now apply the statistical methods in Section III to the data in [5] (described in Section II-B).

context.text: Many papers, e.g., [8], [12], have applied such techniques to crack growth and used them to predict times at which cracks pass some critical level for both the specimens under test and future ones.
This paper extends the work of [8] and [12] wherein the basic crack growth law [10] was used in the analysis.

Reference [13] suggests the following form for \$\Delta K\$ for a specimen of width \$2W\$ and thickness \$t\$:
If \$W\$ is large relative to \$a\$, then \$\sec (\cdot)\approx 1\$ in (2.2); and then \$\Delta K\approx\Delta \sigma\cdot\sqrt{\pi\cdot a\,}\$, which conveniently allows (2.1) to be solved as
This is essentially the equation in [8] and [12].

links.abstract: Micro-cracks are generally defined to be cracks less than 1 mm in length, which propagate under cyclic stresses until they grow large and cause failure in an item (e.g. component or structure). This paper proposes a method of using data on 'fatigue micro-crack growth in a material' to predict its reliability. It is increasingly important to model such cracks effectively, Their growth properties, which differ in several respects from larger cracks, are discussed. The paper develops a hierarchical...

context.text: A similar modeling framework was used [15] to assess reliability from fatigue microcrack growth.

references.title: Reliability assessment from fatigue micro-crack data
references.text: S. P. Wilson, D. Taylor, "Reliability assessment from fatigue micro-crack data", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 46, pp. 165-172, 1997.
